Description: Body sherd of Attic-black figured pottery dinos; interior glazed black; exterior: black figure decoration consisting of three animal friezes separated by black bands with superimposed red; top: feline hind legs to left (with trace of added red); centre: boar to left (red markings on body); two incised rosettes with red dots on petals and centres as filling ornament; below panther to right (head and shoulder remaining; red on forehead and shoulder); top of wing of siren or sphinx; incised rosette as filling ornament.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.
The sherd belongs to the same vase as Toronto 910X234.14 (C16).
Bibliographic references: Venit 1982 / Painted Pottery from the Greek Mainland found in Egypt, 640-450 BC (p. 288-9, no. B264)
Möller 2000 / Naukratis, Trade in Archaic Greece (p. 226, no. 2b)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GA.0246) (Phase 1)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 91-2, pl. I, no. 19)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
